SubjectNoHTML: taki - Sparse Network Simulation Question
TransactionContent: Hi [USER], From what I can find there is no way to force slurm to run all at the same time, but there are a few workarounds we can try. First, you can specify nodes which are in the 'idle' (meaning no resources are being used) state using the '--nodelist' flag. Note that using this flag will make it so that your jobs will only run on the specified node list so make sure you do the math on the resources requested. Second, you can use '--hold' flag in the command to put all your jobs into a pending state until the resources are available. You'll then have to manually release the job using 'scontrol release $job_number' once you see the available nodes. As an aside, one of the nice things about using sbatch is that you can put all of the flags/options in the slurm file that you are submitting as an sbatch, and not have to rewrite it every time you want to resubmit the job. For example in your slurm file here you could write: '#!/bin/bash #SBATCH --time=30 #SBATCH --qos=normal+ #SBATCH --account=[STAFF] #SBATCH --partition=cpu_2021 #SBATCH --cpus-per-task=1 #SBATCH --array=0-5 #SBATCH --hold' Finally, note that there is no partition called 'batch' anymore (they were shutdown as of august 2023). The names of the partitions can be found here https://hpcf.umbc.edu/system-description-taki/. Hope this helps, and let me know if you need further assistance. I want to start doing some experiments again for my side project that involve simulating sparse networks on Taki. The last time I did one of these experiments, which has been months at this point, I used a Slurm command along the lines of this: sbatch --time=30 --qos=normal+ --account=[STAFF] --partition=batch -c 1 --array=0-199 `pwd`/ddlserver.slurm $modelfolder 200 buildnetwork $seed. The issue with this command was that, depending on the load on the cluster, some fraction of the intended 200 jobs used to simulate the 200 node network would be launched, but they would timeout before the rest of the 200 jobs were launched. In order for the code to run correctly, all 200 jobs need to be running at the same time. Is there a way to let Slurm know that all the jobs need to be launched at the same time and that they should be held until that is possible? Is there also some way to let Slurm know that the jobs primarily spend their time sleeping while they wait for other nodes on the network to finish processing their data? The last time I worked on this project, I did try to look through the Slurm documentation to look for flags and environment variables that could help the simulations run more smoothly, but I never was able to find anything that worked the way I wanted it to. Please let me know if you have any ideas for the best way for me to proceed.

SubjectNoHTML: ada - Few people tried using all possible resources on the ADA clusters
TransactionContent: I don't see any of your jobs in the queue currently or in the screenshots, so I am assuming this issue is resolved. Remember that jobs should never be expected to immediately run on a shared resource. Jobs that don't immediately run are then in a 'pending' or 'PD' state. Slurm determines which job from the set of PD jobs should run next based on three factors: 1) How long the PD jobs has been waiting to run, 2) How frequently the user's group has been running jobs, and 3) How large the job is (smaller jobs have slightly more priority). Item 1 means that any job you desire to run should be submitted ASAP and left for slurm to run when slurm can identify the resources. Item 2 means that users who have been 'hogging' the cluster quickly see their jobs de-prioritized in favor of users who have submitted jobs but not used the cluster as much. As I write this [STAFF] is unable to run additional jobs due to this deprioritization and jobs submitted by [USER] are slated next to run (see the output below). Item 3 doesn't factor much into the issue I believe you're communicating, but exists nonetheless. Further, no job can run on requested resources for more than 72 hours. This is due to preemption rules that exist on the cluster, but this preemption don't seem to have been at play given the timeframe of this ticket. SubjectNoHTML: Other - Chip ssh keys for autologin
TransactionContent: Here is the cleaned text: You can generate ssh keys for use on [SERVER] (I would recommend using newer encryption: 'ssh-keygen -t ed25519') this will not however bypass the 2-factor requirement. The SSH key would take the place of your password but you would still need to 2-factor during login. The only way to bypass the 2-factor is to connect via the [NETWORK] VPN. This is the case because the VPN already enforces 2-factor. You would then only have to 2-factor during the initial VPN connection and could subsequently use ssh to [SERVER] with the SSH key as long as the VPN session remains active. The underlying security requirement is the 2-factor step must be in the authentication path. Unfortunately the Linux authentication stack does not retain any information on prior successes or failures so each time you must satisfy all steps in the stack, even if you start 2 nearly simultaneous sessions both would have independent authentication paths.
